text: on a routine patrol near Baghdad
sergeant Angela Erb comes under fire
she's a target like any other soldier
but according to US military policy she
is officially not in a ground combat
situation this is Lisette Alvarez with
the New York Times since 2001 women have
taken fire patrolled war zones served as
Gunners even been killed in hostile
action women are side-by-side with males
and we've broken down that barrier those
misconceptions about what we can and
can't do when official military policy
prohibits women from direct ground
combat I mean if you have to be able to
lift a certain amount of weight in order
to do a certain job then you know the
weights not going to know that whether
you're male or female I understand why
they don't want females in a combat
situation
how it works with the guys that you
become their sister if something was to
ever happen to you by the enemy you
could be used in front of them to make
them talk today more than three hundred
and fifty six thousand women serve in
the Armed Forces including in the
National Guard and Reserve the largest
number ever in past Wars women served
mostly behind the front lines as medics
and support staff but in Iraq and
Afghanistan where there are no front
lines on the ground experience for women
is outpacing military policy my last
deployment we took small arms fire we
got hit with V bids IEDs that kind of
stuff pretty regularly
contradictions abound for example women
officers can lead some all-male troops
into conflict but technically they can't
serve among them in battle when I think
about leading troops in combat
I don't consider the fact that I'm a
woman I'm more concerned with getting
the job done completing the mission and
taking care of the soldiers at the start
of these Wars there was concern that
Americans weren't ready to see women
coming home in body bags but the latest
New York Times CBS News poll indicates
that this is not the case
women have demonstrated courage and
confidence in combat situations winning
medals of Valor in the process
whether or not official policy catches
up with wartime reality the experiences
of women in combat are now well known
inside the military and for a group of
young cadets at West Point the potential
dangers are clear I don't feel like
being a female I'm particularly prone to
freaking out or anything like that I
mean you're going to war you're gonna
you might be shot at
there's roadside bombs there's tons of
uncertainty that degree of uncertainty
it exists in everyone's mind but without
it you'd be complacent so but changes to
military policy are likely to trigger
emotional debates in Congress so as
troops moved from Iraq into Afghanistan
women may still face combat on the
ground if not officially on paper it's
getting the point where it's time to
relook things I think and relook policy
and ask if this really makes sense
